titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Urban Poverty Program, Office Files of Mark Elliott
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Urban Poverty Program, Office Files of Mark Elliott FA1713

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-03-13 18:09:05 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Urban Poverty Program, Office Files of Mark Elliott

physdesc.extent: 28 letter document boxes and 1 legal document box

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Ford Foundation has title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This material was transferred to the RAC in 2019 and was ingested by the RAC as Accession 2019:114.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection consists of one series of subject files. The records' creators imposed an inconsistent alphabetical arrangement on the files.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Founder and President of the Economic Mobility Corporation, Mark Elliott has made a career in both public service and philanthropy. During the early to mid-1990s, he worked as a Program Officer in the Ford Foundation's Urban Poverty Program where he was responsible for managing the Foundation's grants to housing and economic development projects.

Elliott founded the Economic Mobility Corporation in 2007. In addition to his work with the Ford Foundation and Mobility, he has served as Deputy Budget Director of the City of New York and worked as an executive vice president for Public/Private Ventures.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Collection contains the office files of Mark Elliott who worked as a Program Officer in the Ford Foundation's Urban Poverty Program during the early to mid-1990s. The collection is comprised of one series of subject files. Elliott's subject files document his activities for managing grants to housing and economic development programs, research studies, and projects as well as his participation in the Urban Poverty Program's planning and strategizing efforts. Materials within the collection extend back from before Elliott's tenure at the Foundation up until the point where the Urban Poverty Program was set to transition to become part of the new Asset Building and Community Development Program (ASSETS) in 1996.

The collection chiefly consists of correspondence, memos, notes, drafts, reports, press clippings, newsletters, brochures, publications, schedules, agendas, and Recommended Grant Action records (RGAs). Documents show that during Elliot's tenure as a Program Officer, the Urban Poverty Program supported and engaged with organizations and projects concerned with economic development, community development, housing, employment and job training, housing discrimination and segregation, urban reinvestment, and anti-poverty strategies.

physdesc.extent: 28 LTR size and 1 LGL size Hollinger boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains the subject files Mark Elliott created when he worked as a Program Officer in the Ford Foundation's Urban Poverty Program. The files document the Foundation's support of programs, research studies, and projects concerned with economic development, community development, housing, homeownership, employment and job training, housing preservation, minority owned businesses, housing discrimination and segregation, self-sufficiency, urban reinvestment, and anti-poverty strategies. Common material formats found throughout the series include correspondence, memos, reports, drafts, notes, press clippings, newsletters, brochures, publications, agendas, schedules, and Recommended Grant Actions records (RGAs). Although Elliott served as a Program Officer in the 1990s, his files include material from as early as 1965. These records document the Urban Poverty Program's earlier work that extended into Elliott's tenure as well as older research papers and articles that Elliott acquired.

Elliott's correspondence chiefly consists of communications with grantees and potential grantees, staff members from the Urban Poverty Program and the larger Ford Foundation, and other individuals involved with the housing and urban economic development fields. The series' contents show the impact of national public housing legislation and policy on the programs seeking and receiving Foundation support and on the urban economic development field with which Elliott engaged. Many records discuss the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) and the housing policies of the George H. W. Bush and Bill Clinton Presidential Administrations.

In addition to the files documenting Elliott's responsibilities for managing the Ford Foundation's housing and economic development grants, there are several files in the series that regard the planning and strategizing of the Urban Poverty Program. Among this material is a group of records which discuss the transitioning of the Urban Poverty Program to become part of the Asset Building and Community Development Program (ASSETS) in 1996.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Suburban Job-Link Corp photo ID pass in the files was made for Mark Elliott to use.
